reporting_cycle: semi-annually, not later than forty-five days prior to its expiration
summary:
The Security Council:

* Coordinates international electoral assistance to Haiti's government with stakeholders (OAS, UNASUR, CARICOM) (para 7).
* Encourages Haiti's government to promote women's political participation (para 8).
* Stresses strengthening the Haitian National Police (HNP) is crucial for stability and development (para 9).
* Requests MINUSTAH to continue building HNP's capacity, particularly through mentoring and training (para 10).
* Urges support for the 2012-2016 HNP Development Plan to achieve 15,000 operational police officers by 2016 (para 11).
* Requests close coordination among MINUSTAH, donors, and Haiti's government to enhance HNP capacity-building (para 12).
* Encourages MINUSTAH to assist in tackling gang violence, organized crime, and trafficking (para 13).
* Encourages Haiti's authorities to implement justice reform and address prolonged pretrial detentions and prison conditions (para 14).
* Calls on donors to coordinate efforts through Haiti's Framework for the Coordination of External Aid (CAED) (para 15).
* Requests the UN country team and actors to complement security and development operations with activities improving living conditions (para 16).
* Requests MINUSTAH to implement quick-impact projects contributing to a secure environment and national ownership (para 17).
* Condemns grave violations against children and sexual abuse of women and girls, and calls for protection of their rights (para 18).
* Encourages MINUSTAH to assist in providing protection to civilians, particularly internally displaced persons and vulnerable groups (para 19).
* Requests the Secretary-General to ensure MINUSTAH personnel comply with the zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse (para 20).
* Reaffirms MINUSTAH's human rights mandate and urges respect and protection of human rights by HNP and the judiciary (para 21).
* Encourages MINUSTAH to use existing means to enhance stability and Haitian ownership (para 22).
* Requests MINUSTAH to continue its community violence reduction approach, focusing on at-risk youth and vulnerable groups (para 23).
The Security Council:

Supports the work of the UN country team to build local capacity;

Requests MINUSTAH to support Haitian authorities in controlling small arms flow, developing a weapons registry, revising laws on arms importation and possession, reforming the weapons permit system, and implementing a national community policing doctrine;
